timeline.message:
Begin refactor work:
Sand -> Aggregate
Underwater Plant -> Aquatic Plant
Bamboo Sapling -> Bamboo Shoot
Part -> Decoration
Packed Ice -> Dense Ice
Organic -> Fodder
Pumpkin -> Gourd
Clay -> Mob Derived
Anvil -> Repair Station
Seagrass -> Replaceable Aquatic Plant
Snow -> Snow Layer
Earth -> Topsoil

timeline.bodyText: Ive not heard of this before, not sure what other people think?
timeline.author: modmuss50

replies.bodyText: GOURD is fine. We also have a GourdBlock class.
replies.author: Juuxel

timeline.bodyText: Whats the reasoning behind this? SNOW seems fine?
timeline.author: modmuss50

replies.bodyText: I agree, especially since the block is minecraft:snow.
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: To make it clearer between SNOW_BLOCK and SNOW
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: I also want to clarify this since 1.17 (iirc the right version) will have "snowier snow," so I want to clarify this as much as possible so that it doesn't become out of date soon
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: We don't yet know what Mojang is going to do. I'd rather change it later than change it now and later find out the change was in the wrong direction.
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: As it stands now, this name still clarifies the blocks that use this material.
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: This is used by dirt as well. I dont think this is correct
timeline.author: modmuss50

replies.bodyText: Dirt is considered topsoil as well
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Dirt is not exclusively topsoil.
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: yes, but everything with this material can be described as topsoil. The purpose of this name is to narrow down the overgeneralized name of "earth" to make it more descriptive. "Earth" is far too broad, so if you have an alternative name I'm open to suggestions.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Not really an improvement
replies.author: Prospector

replies.bodyText: "Earth" is too broad of a name. "Topsoil" is closer to what the blocks are.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Shouldn't "topsoil" be two words? TOP_SOIL
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: Topsoil is one word.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Still don't think this is an improvement.
replies.author: Prospector

replies.bodyText: Changed to SOIL as per feedback
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: Not sure on the reasoning behind this, its only used by clay?
timeline.author: modmuss50

replies.bodyText: It's not, it's used by infested blocks, honey blocks, honeycomb blocks, and slime blocks. Clay is the odd man out
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: what is the property of the material?
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: Has the same properties as EARTH, SAND, NETHER_WOOD, and a few others, only differing in the color
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: just say "xxx colored earth"
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: CLAY can also be considered decayed organic material from animals, so it somewhat fits with this name.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: SQUISHY
replies.author: bluebear94

replies.bodyText: What about clay makes it MOB_DERIVED? What does that even mean?
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText:
Realistically, clay is made of organic material, usually from animals (mobs).
Every other block with this material is from some action or produce of a mob, ie derived from a mob.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: No, the names should reflect how they are prgramatically used. This material has nothing to do with entities
replies.author: kvverti

replies.bodyText: Simply keep with how they are programmatically used is not in keeping with how Materials have ever been named, and to switch to such a system would only add confusion.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: This one definitely doesn't work since clay isn't "MOB_DERIVED" and even for the other blocks that are, it's a very strange name. SQUISHY is pretty good, as suggested above.
replies.author: Prospector

replies.bodyText: Another suggestion was "moldable." Will hold off editing for more feedback.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Does it make sense to call anything "moldable" when molding isn't a thing you can do in minecraft?
replies.author: immibis

timeline.bodyText: Why the change here, is called Packed ice in vanilla?
timeline.author: modmuss50

replies.bodyText: It's also used for blue ice, which is another type of dense ice.
replies.author: Juuxel

timeline.bodyText: Again, not sure the resaoning behind this?
timeline.author: modmuss50

replies.bodyText: Yeah, it's only used for both types of seagrass.
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText:
And ANVIL used to only be used for anvils, and now the name is misleading. This material only differs from AQUATIC_PLANT by being replaceable, so changing this is to make it clearer to devs who want to get any of the plants that exist underwater.
This also brings it more inline with what PLANT was already doing in terms of naming
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: No, this is used by more than just decroation blocks?
timeline.author: modmuss50

replies.bodyText: I'm open to suggestions, but PART isn't very descriptive
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText:
Used for skulls, torches, potted plants, ladders, redstone components, and rails.
Perhaps SUBBLOCK?
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: like fluid loggable block? redstone components and rails are circuits
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText:
None of the blocks in this material are fluid loggable (except maybe ladders).
If SUBBLOCK is already in use for fluid logging then that won't work for a material name in this case. PART seems like a multipart or part of something else, which these are not. Initially chose DECORATION as that's what's on the wiki (per the original issue), and PART is just too vague.
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: This sounds a bit weird. It's used for powder-like falling blocks (sands, soul sand, gravel and concrete powder), so maybe POWDER?
timeline.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: or FALLABLE?
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: I prefer AGGREGATE over POWDER. FALLABLE is not in keeping with the rest of the materials being some descriptor of what the blocks are/are made from
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Aggregate is vaguely familliar. Looking it up, I get the definition "a natural mixture of sand, gravel, and crushed stone" in the context of geology, though I agree it's a little too technical. If you use it, this will require a Javadoc.
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aggregate_(geology)
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: Aggregate is a fairly common term. Regardless, it is more descriptive of these blocks than "sand" or "powder."
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: perhaps PARTICLES?
replies.author: Prospector

replies.bodyText: "Particles" is used elsewhere by the game, and you can't really call gravel particles. "Aggregate" is more descriptive.
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: The block is minecraft:bamboo_sapling. (see also #1189 (comment))
timeline.author: Juuxel
Juuxel

replies.bodyText:
Dried kelp can be used for food, and I'm ignoring the odd man out of mycelium.
The goal is to make the name clearer as to what blocks it represents. Suggestions are welcome.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: compared to clay, this one is like raw biomass/living biomass while clay/honey block etc are non-living bio-derived stuff
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText:
the fodder is that most of the blocks in it are a food source, or storage of one
I'm implying that mooshrooms eat mycelium with that name, but fodder encompasses most of the blocks in that material
since organic is far too broad
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText:
ORGANIC -> BIO or BIOMASS
I'm not sure what fodder means, other than something you throw dock for pigs to eat.
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: Fodder is the storage of food for later use. This or a synonym would function well. Biomass is far too general for this group.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Not an improvement because it loses accuracy for certain of the blocks with the material
replies.author: Prospector

replies.bodyText: FODDER -> SOLID_ORGANIC to better encompass all the blocks that use it, and to narrow down the blocks it applies to
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: FORGING_STATION like
timeline.author: liach

replies.bodyText: This material does not include the smithing table, so FORGING_STATION seems odd
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: good
replies.author: liach

timeline.message: AQUATIC -> UNDERWATER to account for lily pad being under PLANT

.>material for -barrier- metal blocks.
Uuuh....

Co-Authored-By: liach <7806504+liach@users.noreply.github.com>

timeline.bodyText: Is this really necessary? It's not enough that the name of the field is WATER, we have to specify that it's for water too?
timeline.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: Likewise applies to other jds in this PR.
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: Did it for consistency, and because blocks could be added to this material at any time, so would need the JD/rename at that point.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Doesn't address the issue. These comments are all redundant.
replies.author: Sollace

timeline.bodyText: All ice can melt (irl). Rather specify on the other one that it's for ice that can't melt, or specify here which one to use for ice that cannot melt instead.
timeline.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText: Not all ice in MC can melt. That is included in the JD because it isn't included in the name.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText:
All ice can melt (In Real Life) is what I mean. Meltable is the default state and implied by the name "ice".
Saying that this is ice that can melt is redundant. You should rather mention where the behaviour is a divergence from the expected behaviour.
Hence, don't say this is ice that can melt, say the other one is ice that cannot melt and link to it from this one.
replies.author: Sollace

replies.bodyText:
yes, the name ice implies that it is meltable, but it also implies that it is all ice, which it is not.
A link to the unmeltable kind can be added, but keeping what is already there in the JD will enhance clarity
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.message:
Remove missed old name

Co-Authored-By: liach <7806504+liach@users.noreply.github.com>

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            		COMMENT Material for ice that can melt. {@see DENSE_ICE} for unmeltable ice.
          
          
            
            		COMMENT Material for ice that can melt. See {@link #DENSE_ICE} for unmeltable ice.
timeline.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: Redundant. The name already says everything you need to know.
timeline.author: Sollace

timeline.bodyText: Why does this need to change? PART was fine, and if you're going to change it at least make it SUB_BLOCK.
timeline.author: Sollace

timeline.bodyText: A more descriptive name for UNUSED_PLANT would be nice for people wanting to use it
timeline.author: Prospector

replies.bodyText: I think javadoc would be better in this case, as something like "plant_not_used_by_vanilla" is a bit awkward.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Javadoc for it was added, if a rename is desired it can be done
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: Sub block seems like a bit of an odd name to me because they're still just normal blocks. I think PART is just fine personally.
timeline.author: Prospector

replies.bodyText: "Part" to me seems like a part of something, and since MC doesn't have multiparts or anything really that is assembled from "parts" it seems odd to me.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: PARTIAL_BLOCK?
replies.author: YanisBft

replies.bodyText: How is "partial" any different from "sub"?
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: sub usually indicates an inclusion, so people would assume it to belong to a bigger block or a multiblock. partial doesn't have this ambiguity
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: CHanged to PARTIAL
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: grass or grass blocks?
timeline.author: YanisBft

replies.bodyText: Updated.
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: The nether fungi aren't wood.
timeline.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: Unfortunately, mojang considers them wood.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Well, they're wood-like but not "nether wood logs".
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: The tags call them wood, they belong to the logs category, they can be used to craft wood items such as chests and sticks - they are functionally wood.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Just "nether logs" should suffice; logs are type of wood
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: logs will not, as the planks and other nether wood blocks use this material.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText:
This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters

            		COMMENT Material for blocks crafted from stems (Nether wood logs).
          
          
            
            		COMMENT Material for blocks crafted from stems (Nether logs).
          
      
    
    
  

what's wrong with this description
replies.author: liach

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            		COMMENT Hard solid nonmetallic mineral matter of which rock is made, especially as a building material.
          
      
    
    
  

I don't think we need to describe the chemical composition of stone in Yarn javadocs (especially here).
timeline.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: Rather than mentioning chemical composition, we may consider mentioning their breaking property (i.e. blocks that general can only be harvested with pickaxes and be broken faster with pickaxes)
replies.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: Mention Minecraft features of these blocks, such as explosion resistance, color, breaking information, harvest information, etc.
timeline.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: Really? Isn't nether stem stuff under NETHER_WOOD?
timeline.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: MOB_DERIVED is not a good name. I like SQUISHY, and ORGANIC_PRODUCT could also work (inspired by @liach's comment: #1190 (comment)).
timeline.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: I like SQUISHY.
replies.author: LoganDark

replies.bodyText: Could just be ORGANIC in general
replies.author: NeusFear

replies.bodyText: ORGANIC itself will not work, as that is too broad. If ORGANGIC_PRODUCT is what is wanted, sure.
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.bodyText: Not sure this one is descriptive. I'd consider a slab a "partial block"
timeline.author: Earthcomputer

replies.bodyText: What's this material for?
replies.author: 2xsaiko

replies.bodyText:
well, would be more common to assume slabs share material with their full block counterparts.
This material is for things like redstone components, rails, torches, ladders, etc.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: A material does not describe a block shape. It describes a subset of its properties. PARTIAL_BLOCK is not a good name because it describes its shape rather than its properties.
replies.author: Earthcomputer

replies.bodyText: That is not how any material is named, except in cases of clarifying it from another similar property.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: What about MOUNTED? SUPPORTED?
replies.author: 2xsaiko

replies.bodyText: SUPPORTED would be fine, if we're ok ignoring flower pots and the potted plants.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: That's a bug, so SUPPORTED seems good to me https://bugs.mojang.com/browse/MC-127036
replies.author: Prospector

replies.bodyText: Not confirmed as a bug, but we'll go with it then.
replies.author: dexman545

replies.bodyText: Skulls tho?
replies.author: YanisBft

replies.bodyText: i think skull needs a block to attach to as well, so SUPPORTED works very well
replies.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: Since this is used for skulls, supported doesn't work. I'd go with PART or COMPONENT.
timeline.author: Prospector

replies.bodyText: @Prospector #1190 (comment)
replies.author: Earthcomputer

replies.bodyText: That was before I realized skulls were part of it, which aren't "supported." Also, support isn't a property of materials so tbh thinking about it more it really doesn't make sense.
replies.author: Prospector

timeline.bodyText: I think the wording of the javadoc could be simplified a little here: "blocks that come from mobs"?
timeline.author: Earthcomputer

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: dexman545
